Most mod problems are individual, but here was my fix for the OneDrive error (also causes insufficient space error) 

1. Disable OneDrive Folder Redirection
- Open the OneDrive app on your PC (not the browser).
- Open Settings.
- Go to Backup / Manage Folder Backup.
- Uncheck Desktop, Documents, and Pictures.
- When prompted: select “Only on this device”.
- Then open OneDrive: Account -> Unlink this PC.
2. Ensure the Documents Folder Is Local Again
- Open: C:/Users/NAME/Documents
- The folder should no longer show a OneDrive cloud icon.
- The OneDrive version of Documents should no longer exist.
3. Verify the Klei Folder
- Path: C:/Users/NAME/Documents/Klei
- This folder must be local.
- The OneDrive version must NOT exist anymore.
4. Repair Steam Permissions
- Right-click on C:/Program Files (x86)/Steam → Properties → Security.
- Change the owner to your local user account.
- Select your user → allow Full Control.
- If your Microsoft account also appears → allow Full Control as well.
5. Repair the Steam Workshop Folder
- Path: C:/Program Files (x86)/Steam/steamapps/workshop
- Set the owner to your local user.
- Allow Full Control for your user.
6. Restart Steam
- Fully close Steam.
- Start Steam normally (not as administrator).
7. Start Oxygen Not Included Fully
- Launch ONI.
- Start a new colony and load into the world.
- Stay in-game for 20–30 seconds.
- Exit the game properly via the menu.
8. Force Steam to Initialize the Workshop
- Open Steam (normal mode).
- Open the ONI Workshop.
- Unsubscribe from a mod.
- Immediately subscribe again.
- Steam should now download workshop items.
- The folder C:/Program Files (x86)/Steam/steamapps/workshop/content/457140 should appear.
9. Test ONI
- Start ONI again.
- Mods should now appear in the mod menu.
- ONI is now stable and functional.
10. Safely Re-enable OneDrive
- Sign back into OneDrive.
- Only enable sync for Desktop and Pictures.
- Do NOT enable sync for Documents.

What can I say about this contemporary masterpiece of a game.

It’s easily one of the best (if not the best) colony sims out there, and it has eaten a lot of hours of my life. It’s actually my most played game on Steam, and for a very simple reason: it’s absurdly fun to learn and to play.

This game wakes up your inner scientist, your inner administrator, rancher, farmer, electrician, astronomer… you name it. And it does all of that with vivid colors and Klei’s unmistakable sense of humor. If you have kids, they’ll absolutely love it, and they’ll learn plenty about science and data management along the way.

You’ll start out knowing little to nothing about the mechanics and the physics that keep your base alive. You’ll flush several colonies down the toilet because you didn’t know how to prevent certain disasters that appear as the game moves into the mid and late stages. But that’s fine, every failure is just another chance to try again and get a bit closer to your goals. There’s a lot of trial and error, and that’s a big part of the charm.

If you end up falling in love with the game (like I did), you’ll probably start designing your own machines to solve whatever problems you run into, and maybe even share your creations online. There are a couple of communities out there that will welcome you and your creations, and will gladly give you a hand whenever you’re stuck. Toxicity is surprisingly rare around this game.

Excel and the Wiki will be your best friends. Those tools are incredibly helpful when you start planning the future of your base.

At the end of the day, ONI is one of those games that rewards curiosity, creativity, and persistence in equal measure. It doesn’t hold your hand, but it never feels unfair. It simply invites you to understand its world one mistake at a time. If you’re looking for a game that will challenge you, surprise you, and keep you thinking long after you’ve closed it, this one is absolutely worth your time.

Lo, hearken unto my words, and I shall tell thee why Oxygen Not Included standeth above all other games, peerless in craft and cunning design.

In sooth, the makers of this game wrought a marvel most rare: a realm beneath the earth wherein tiny folk, called duplicants, strive mightily to survive. Each moment is a trial of wit, for the very air they breathe may turn against them, and water—aye, even the purest drop—may become bane or blessing.

The game rewardeth those of keen mind and patient hand. Every contrivance, be it pump, furnace, or wondrous machine of heat and steam, must needs be placed with foresight and wisdom. Thus the player becometh both steward and architect, guiding a fragile colony through peril and scarcity.

Moreover, Oxygen Not Included offereth a depth unmatched: the dance of gases, the humours of heat and cold, the cunning paths of power and pipe. Few other games dare weave such subtle workings, nor grant the joy that cometh when chaos is bent at last to order.

Verily, ’tis a tale of triumph against the void, of humble folk thriving where naught was meant to live. And for this reason, many proclaim it the greatest game ever forged—an endless well of challenge and delight, fit for those who would test their mettle ’gainst the very laws of nature.

Thus I speak, and thus it stands.

Oxygen Not Included has been living rent‑free in my head since 2017, when I first watched Markiplier play it and fell in love with the chaos, charm, and brain‑melting base building. I didn’t even own a PC back then, but this game sat on my wishlist for years, and finally getting to play it after all that time genuinely feels like ticking off a long‑awaited life goal.

This game is absolutely not for every type of gamer, and that’s one of the things that makes it special. If your usual diet is twitchy FPS lobbies and competitive Call of Duty matches, the slow, thoughtful, trial‑and‑error rhythm of ONI might feel brutal at first, because it demands planning, learning from failure, and a lot of patience. But if you are willing to step out of your comfort zone, there is a uniquely satisfying joy in watching a doomed‑looking colony slowly evolve into a functioning, self‑sustaining machine.

Klei, as a studio, is one of the last remaining “gameplay first” gods in the industry, and Oxygen Not Included and Don’t Starve are perfect examples of that philosophy. Instead of chasing trends or building yet another battle royale full of microtransactions and bloated battle passes, they focus on tight, clever design, expressive art, and systems that respect your intelligence and time. ONI, in particular, rewards curiosity and experimentation in a way that few modern games do.

What impresses me most is how Klei has supported this game over the years. Even long after release, they have continued to push out updates, refinements, and new content, treating ONI and their other titles like living projects instead of disposable products, which makes this an easy pick for the Steam “Labor of Love” award in my book. You can feel that they are not trying to make the biggest cash‑cow on the market; they are trying to make something genuinely good, interesting, and fun to play for the long haul.

If you love deep simulation, puzzling through problems, and the “one more cycle” addiction, Oxygen Not Included is absolutely worth your time, especially if you also enjoy Klei’s other masterpiece, Don’t Starve. And if you’re that COD‑queue warrior who’s even a little bit curious, do yourself a favor: step outside the comfort zone, fire up ONI (or Don’t Starve), and discover just how satisfying a real labor‑of‑love game can be.

A fun survival-oriented management game in the spirit of dwarf fortress. Set in space with lots of cute animals, interesting systems, and emergent ways for your colony of duplicants to fail spectacularly. Once you get the hang of it, the survival aspects aren't too hard to navigate, and the real fun of developing sustainability begins.

When the game first launched, it had few systems for automation and transport. Over time, these have been added in, including fanciful mechanics that can be used to build base-sized computers, rocket engines, sour gas boilers, and all kinds of late-game puzzles. I tend to play it like a cozy game, which means I get stuck in the sustainability phase, and never reach the intricate systems portion. 

That might be all for the best, though, as many of the things that the designers put in don't quite work. Airlock doors are a good example. They do what they should--prevent gasses from moving through--but creating an actual airlock is nearly impossible. Instead, the community uses the water mechanics creatively to trap gasses in various areas. 

The solutions are cool (when they're not horrific), but so many of the things that you need to create a sustainable base just don't seem to use the tools you unlock. When I play, I tend to get most of the tech stuff done long before I need it, and have a lot of equipment that is semi-useless for long periods. 

Towards the middle game, everything seems to work in spite of the mechanics, or by gaming the sim in ways that range from "mildly broken" (creating infinite water by recycling polluted water through sinks and toilets) to "outright cheating" (infinite gas storage). It's fun to play with these things, but the game looses a little of its charm as you realize that you can't really accomplish the cool stuff without cheesing it.

Even so, after 100 hours I still want to pick it up and play. It's a great game, just one that hasn't lived up to the potential I see in the tech tree.

Many years later, this is now a comfort game for me. Am I good at it? Eh, somewhat, but I'm not good enough at maths and physics to be stellar at it and I'm often more focused on making it things a nice layout rather than making efficient mechanisms.

Every time I start up a game of Oxygen Not Included, I get to about the mid-point thinking, "oh this game is kinda cool, maybe I should get some of those DLCs!" Then something fucking stupid happens, like a duplicate deciding to stand in the boiling water instead of the ladder to build a heat tile until it scalds them into a pain coma.

"That sucks." I think, eyebrow twitching in consternation. "Hopefully the other duplicates will save- wait, what the fuck-" Other duplicates start dropping one by one because there's steam coming up through the drainage vents and forming scalding puddles they would rather burn their feet in than follow my mop directive. Always follow the mop directive! There are still a few duplicates left, but I noticed they aren't saving the ones who are dying of their own stupidity. Why is that? Oh, all the medical beds are full so the rest just die I guess.

I don't see why a regular bed wouldn't work in a life-or-death situation, but whatever. Maybe I can build more before-wait, the survivors are going to sleep now. I guess I could activate red alert and send them scrambling, but now I want them to suffer. "You should have listened to me," I solemnly inform them. "You were too stupid to live at my benevolence, now experience my malevolence." The only warning I had about any of this was a "scalding!" alert that flashed on the screen for a couple seconds before disappearing while I was wondering whether they would get sucked into space if I breached the planet's surface without atmo suits. I guess we'll never know, now.

If you enjoy spinning plates and logistics to a psychotic degree, this may be enjoyable. For everyone else, you get to spend a dozen hours building up a colony only to find you fucked yourself six hours ago by not adequately configuring your power grids or your water distribution according to the nebulously defined "tutorials" and now everything is going to shit and exploding while your duplicates scheme to trap themselves in the walls or piss all over the drinking water.

The game throws a ridiculous pile of numbers at you, but the lack of basic quality of life features has to be intentional. I get it, these are accurate units of measurement, but I'm also a moron so I need a chart or something to show me how much of one thing correlates to another thing.

A duplicate needs to consume a number of calories each day cycle. Each food item confers a different number of calories. When food is in storage, it's measured by weight. This does not help me. There's an overall calories available number at the top of the screen, but this also doesn't really help me. Will my farms bloom in time or do I have to squeeze out more mud bars, thus drawing vital duplicate labor and power supply away from other tasks?

COME ON! This is just ONE system! I don't want to do equations to figure out how big a farm I need of which plants, based on available cooking options, relative to the number of duplicates, while calculating the resource cost over time.

Why can't you set manufactured consumables to "until you have X"? Cook until you're not hungry, how about that? Why can't I set an alert to let me know a vital resource is running low? You need algae to produce oxygen. I had ten tons of the stuff when I started. Now we're on day 25 and it's ALL gone. When did that happen? Who knows! Why don't my duplicates go lie down when they're at half health instead of staring at the erupting steam geyser?

There's an automation branch to the tech tree that might cover some of this, but I never have time to try any of it because I need to prioritize chasing the next machine that will replenish whichever dwindling resource is keeping them all alive. The amount of data it does make available to you just makes it more jarring when something either isn't covered or is buried somewhere when you need it right now. How many duplicates can I sustain before we reach a critical mass that will burn down the colony in four hours unless I expand right now? I'm sure the numbers are available to figure this out, but also, you're a video game. You can tell me some things and I'll still have fun, honest.

If you can't learn a game by playing it, then it needs to convey its fundamental mechanics better. Some things the game teaches you through catastrophic, cascading failure. Other times you have to examine all the beats involved to figure out what went wrong where, when, and why. "The power went out" can mean a lot of things when you have multiple plants using different fuels via different delivery methods on different grids with different stations drawing power at different quantities at different times. Oh, the duplicates decided not to walk to the other end of the base to pick up the newly mined coal, despite the higher priority.

This may be fun for masochists, but it also represents tens of hours of your life wasted for nothing. You've already got resource management, which covers food, water, air, air flow, temperature, morale, space (area), space (friggin' SPACE), germs, power, plumbing, and travel time. Having to micromanage the stupid little bastards you act through on top of all that becomes needlessly annoying.

This game has a lot going for it, in the sense that juggling all the systems it has can feel somewhat satisfying while it's going well. Which is why I still come back to check it out every couple years. But there are a lot of times I think it confuses obtuse with complex in ways that detract from its appeal.

Then something fucking stupid happens, like a duplicate deciding to stand in the boiling water instead of the ladder to build a heat tile until it scalds them into a pain coma.

"That sucks." I think, eyebrow twitching in consternation. "Hopefully the other duplicates will save- wait, what the fuck-" Other duplicates start dropping one by one because there's steam coming up through the drainage vents and forming scalding puddles they would rather burn their feet in than follow my mop directive. Always follow the mop directive! There are still a few duplicates left, but I noticed they aren't saving the ones who are dying of their own stupidity. Why is that? Oh, all the medical beds are full so the rest just die I guess.

I don't see why a regular bed wouldn't work in a life-or-death situation, but whatever. Maybe I can build more before-wait, the survivors are going to sleep now. I guess I could activate red alert and send them scrambling, but now I want them to suffer. "You should have listened to me," I solemnly inform them. "You were too stupid to live at my benevolence, now experience my malevolence." The only warning I had about any of this was a "scalding!" alert that flashed on the screen for a couple seconds before disappearing while I was wondering whether they would get sucked into space if I breached the planet's surface without atmo suits. I guess we'll never know, now.

If you enjoy spinning plates and logistics to a psychotic degree, this may be enjoyable. For everyone else, you get to spend a dozen hours building up a colony only to find you fucked yourself six hours ago by not adequately configuring your power grids or your water distribution according to the nebulously defined "tutorials" and now everything is going to shit and exploding while your duplicates scheme to trap themselves in the walls or piss all over the drinking water.

The game throws a ridiculous pile of numbers at you, but the lack of basic quality of life features has to be intentional. I get it, these are accurate units of measurement, but I'm also a moron so I need a chart or something to show me how much of one thing correlates to another thing.

A duplicate needs to consume a number of calories each day cycle. Each food item confers a different number of calories. When food is in storage, it's measured by weight. This does not help me. There's an overall calories available number at the top of the screen, but this also doesn't really help me. Will my farms bloom in time or do I have to squeeze out more mud bars, thus drawing vital duplicate labor and power supply away from other tasks?

COME ON! This is just ONE system! I don't want to do equations to figure out how big a farm I need of which plants, based on available cooking options, relative to the number of duplicates, while calculating the resource cost over time.

Why can't you set manufactured consumables to "until you have X"? Cook until you're not hungry, how about that? Why can't I set an alert to let me know a vital resource is running low? You need algae to produce oxygen. I had ten tons of the stuff when I started. Now we're on day 25 and it's ALL gone. When did that happen? Who knows! Why don't my duplicates go lie down when they're at half health instead of staring at the erupting steam geyser?

There's an automation branch to the tech tree that might cover some of this, but I never have time to try any of it because I need to prioritize chasing the next machine that will replenish whichever dwindling resource is keeping them all alive. The amount of data it does make available to you just makes it more jarring when something either isn't covered or is buried somewhere when you need it right now. How many duplicates can I sustain before we reach a critical mass that will burn down the colony in four hours unless I expand right now? I'm sure the numbers are available to figure this out, but also, you're a video game. You can tell me some things and I'll still have fun, honest.

If you can't learn a game by playing it, then it needs to convey its fundamental mechanics better. Some things the game teaches you through catastrophic, cascading failure. Other times you have to examine all the beats involved to figure out what went wrong where, when, and why. "The power went out" can mean a lot of things when you have multiple plants using different fuels via different delivery methods on different grids with different stations drawing power at different quantities at different times. Oh, the duplicates decided not to walk to the other end of the base to pick up the newly mined coal, despite the higher priority.

This may be fun for masochists, but it also represents tens of hours of your life wasted for nothing. You've already got resource management, which covers food, water, air, air flow, temperature, morale, space (area), space (friggin' SPACE), germs, power, plumbing, and travel time. Having to micromanage the stupid little bastards you act through on top of all that becomes needlessly annoying.

This game has a lot going for it, in the sense that juggling all the systems it has can feel somewhat satisfying while it's going well. Which is why I still come back to check it out every couple years. But there are a lot of times I think it confuses obtuse with complex in ways that detract from its appeal.
